subject: Re: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or 	IsCollection.isEmpty()
msgSnippet: Rocco, ... (FYI, you don t.  You state your opinion, the strength of your conviction, and supporting arguments.  I couldn t ask for less.) (And I kind of hope,
messageBody:
Rocco,

On Thu, May 14, 2009 at 10:08 AM, Pigneri, Rocco <rpigneri@...> wrote:
> First off, I apologize if my formatting makes this e-mail hard to read.
> I have been having trouble getting the formatting to work over the
> listserv.  Secondly, I apologize if I come off as overly assertive:

(FYI, you don't. You state your opinion, the strength of your
conviction, and supporting arguments. I couldn't ask for less.)

(And I kind of hope, given the context, that "assertive" was intended
as a pun. :-)

> I strongly disagree.  One of the great strengths of the Hamcrest system
> is the natural readability and self-documentation of the asserts, and
> the proposed change only enhances that.  It's important to look at these
> use cases from the point of view of the user.   For example, in the
> following examples
>
>
>
> assertThat(list.isEmpty());
>
> assertThat(flagNotSet);
>
> assertThat(objectIsNull && listIsEmpty);

Is the intent less clear in

assertTrue(list.isEmpty())?

Let me take this in a different direction. I've wanted, for a while,
to be able to say

assertThat(list).isEmpty();

Using imposterization, this is possible to write, and gives the
wonderful bonus that failure messages can be hamcrest-level
informative, like:

Expected: x.isEmpty()
Actual: x = [a, b, c]

I've created this functionality a number of times, but haven't gotten
around to figure out how to package it: I'm not sure that the number
of dependencies it brings on board would be worth the addition to core
JUnit, but if an interested listener would like to create an extension
package, I'd be one of the first users.

David Saff
